bibl.author: Charles L. Heyde
bibl.title: Charles L. Heyde to Walt Whitman, 5 November, 1890
bibl.orgName: Trent Collection of Whitmaniana, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Duke University

body.p: Fair day—windy however—lake rough—blustering. Han below doing domestic service, doing much better in health— stronger, nervous somewhat, yet doing wonders, after her year of sore trial.

Recieved your imprint, as wonderfullwonderful compilation as classicaly poetic emanations by celebrities from times past, by all degrees. How true you wrote, that time composes, completes the understanding, qualifies the decree, as it were, finaly, justly of degrees, consumate excellence, superiority.
Yourself now Eminent: a Judge. You should have a libreral emolument, or price for this last, most complete production. I feel assured you will.

I remember Bryant. You once brought him to my studio in Brooklyn. I can imagine or recall him now, as he sat on the extreme end of my lounge—High Priest of Nature! Thanatopsis! Durand essayed the theme from his rather weak (never vain palatte.) A failure. The grand old rocks, ancient as the sun, very new rocks" wrote one critic. Cole might, could have portrayed it, with his dramatic power!

And now Walt, I am moved practically, for ourselves, life's subsistence, our homestead for many years, consecrated in a measure by good Mother Whitman's presence, years ago, for a brief sojourn. have on taxes yet 10 dollars, 1 years interest, 15 dollars.
